articles.headline: Bush Defends Iraq War in Speech
articles.snippet: President Bush remained unwavering in his insistence that the invasion of Iraq had made the United States safer.
articles.abstract: President Bush remained unwavering in his insistence that the invasion of Iraq had made the United States safer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush used the fifth anniversary of the start of the war in Iraq on Wednesday to make the case for persevering in a conflict that could have many more anniversaries. Democrats accused him of lacking a strategy to win and withdraw.

articles.headline: Clinton Facing Narrower Path to Nomination
articles.snippet: Winning the nomination has seemed something of a long shot for Hillary Rodham Clinton since February, but it now seems to have grown a bit longer.
articles.abstract: Winning the nomination has seemed something of a long shot for Hillary Rodham Clinton since February, but it now seems to have grown a bit longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton needs three breaks to wrest the Democratic presidential nomination from Senator Barack Obama in the view of her advisers.

articles.headline: Camcorder Brings Zen to the Shoot
articles.snippet: Catching up with the Flip, one of the most popular electronics products of the last year.
articles.abstract: Catching up with the Flip, one of the most popular electronics products of the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Well, this is a little embarrassing. One of the most significant electronics products of the year slipped into the market, became a mega-hit, changed its industry -- and I haven't reviewed it yet.

articles.headline: In Mosul, New Test of Iraqi Army
articles.snippet: The performance of the Iraqi Army suggests that while the forces have made strides, big gaps remain.
articles.abstract: The performance of the Iraqi Army suggests that while the forces have made strides, big gaps remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq  After the Iraqi Army increased patrols in this northern city earlier this year, Col. Haji al-Zibari found himself chasing two insurgents in a weapons-laden truck.

articles.headline: Dismal Year Is Forecast for Car Sales
articles.snippet: The gloomy outlook — reflecting credit turmoil, the housing crisis and the softening economy — will probably lead to more production cuts by car companies.
articles.abstract: The gloomy outlook — reflecting credit turmoil, the housing crisis and the softening economy — will probably lead to more production cuts by car companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The American auto industry is bracing for what may be its worst year in a decade.

articles.headline: At Bear Stearns, Meet the New Boss
articles.snippet: James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, attempted to win over executives at Bear Stearns who have vowed to fight his offer.
articles.abstract: James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, attempted to win over executives at Bear Stearns who have vowed to fight his offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: James Dimon tramped through the rain on Wednesday evening and strode into the headquarters of Bear Stearns, the embattled investment bank he hopes to buy for a mere $2 a share.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In Tibetan Areas, Parallel Worlds Now Collide
articles.snippet: Tibetans and Han Chinese live in close proximity, but their relations are marked by distrust and prejudice.
articles.abstract: Tibetans and Han Chinese live in close proximity, but their relations are marked by distrust and prejudice.
articles.lead_paragraph: GABU VILLAGE, China  For farmers whose lives in this traditionally Tibetan area revolve around its Buddhist temple, an aluminum smelter that belches gray smoke in the distance is less a symbol of material progress than a daily reminder of Chinese disregard.

articles.headline: A Break for Freddie and Fannie
articles.snippet: The regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac eased capital rules in an effort to calm the housing market.
articles.abstract: The regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac eased capital rules in an effort to calm the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the blessing of the Bush administration, the regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, eased a major restriction on the companies on Wednesday in an effort to unfreeze credit markets and stabilize housing prices.

articles.headline: Commodities: Latest Boom, Plentiful Risk
articles.snippet: The booming commodities market offers some weaknesses that are impairing regulators’ ability to protect investors.
articles.abstract: The booming commodities market offers some weaknesses that are impairing regulators’ ability to protect investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The booming commodities market has become increasingly attractive to investors, with hard assets like oil and gold perhaps offering a safe hedge against inflation, as well as the double-digit gains that have fast been disappearing from the markets for stocks, bonds and real estate.

articles.headline: The Affluent, Too, Couldn’t Resist Adjustable Rates
articles.snippet: Even affluent consumers with annual incomes of $100,000 or more are increasingly being ensnared in the home mortgage crisis.
articles.abstract: Even affluent consumers with annual incomes of $100,000 or more are increasingly being ensnared in the home mortgage crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: They took out adjustable-rate mortgages at the peak of the housing bubble to buy homes they would otherwise not be able to afford. Or they refinanced existing mortgages to take cash out. And now, two or three years later, the day of reckoning is here.

articles.headline: Starbucks Plans Return to Its Roots
articles.snippet: Starbucks announced sweeping changes as it seeks to reconnect with customers who have left for competitors or pared back their coffee budget in hard economic times.
articles.abstract: Starbucks announced sweeping changes as it seeks to reconnect with customers who have left for competitors or pared back their coffee budget in hard economic times.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  Howard D. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, announced sweeping changes on Wednesday for the company as it seeks to reconnect with customers who have left for competitors or pared back their coffee budget in hard economic times.
